# Background {.section-title background-image="Slides/section1.PNG" background-size="contain"}

## PSI Schools Outreach {background-image="Slides/main.PNG" background-size="contain"}

::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
PSI supporting Schools Outreach:

- Promoting opportunities in pharmaceutical/ healthcare industry
- Sharing working with data and use of numeracy skills in industry
- Encouraging relevant STEM studies to inspire NextGen into industry
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
<div class="classroom-image"></div>
:::
:::


## Project Objectives {background-image="Slides/main.PNG" background-size="contain"}

We wanted a Shiny application that would fulfill the brief:

-   [Interactive Learning:]{.highlight} Engages students with interactive content & easy to grasp statistical concepts but developing understanding.
-   [Data Literacy:]{.highlight} Aligned with National Curriculum.
-   [Showcase:]{.highlight} Demonstrates the practical use of Statistician & Data Scientist.
-   [Fun & Engaging]{.highlight}

## Constraints {background-image="Slides/main.PNG" background-size="contain"}

-   [Time:]{.highlight} Volunteers with no fixed.
-   [Resources:]{.highlight} No defined budget.
-   [Governance:]{.highlight} Commercial Conflicts & GDPR.
-   [Logistical:]{.highlight} Deployment model.
-   [Known Unknowns:]{.highlight} Different class sizes, equipment, levels of engagement.

## Workshop Workflow {background-image="Slides/main.PNG" background-size="contain"}

Previous workshops lasted **c.**45 - 60 mins had a general workflow. Where would Shiny fit in and would it potential distract?

```{mermaid}
flowchart LR
  A(Introduction) --> B{Randomisation}
  B --> C{Practical Experiment}
  C --> D{Data Recording/Entry}
  D --> E{Statistical Analysis}
  E --> F(Conclusion)
```

## Which Graphs?

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
```{r }
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species, y = flipper_length_mm, fill = species)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Boxplot of Flipper Length by Penguin Species",
       x = "Species",
       y = "Flipper Length (mm)") +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c(
    "Adelie" = "#18213B",
    "Chinstrap" = "#89D8C1",
    "Gentoo" = "#CD8581"
  )) +
  coord_flip()
```

Aligned with curriculum and classroom learning.
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
```{r }
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species, y = flipper_length_mm, fill = species)) +
  geom_violin() +
  labs(title = "Violin of Flipper Length by Penguin Species",
       x = "Species",
       y = "Flipper Length (mm)") +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c(
    "Adelie" = "#18213B",
    "Chinstrap" = "#89D8C1",
    "Gentoo" = "#CD8581"
  )) +
  coord_flip()

```
Tempted... 
but looks like abstract art to the uninitiated.
:::
:::

## Interactivity

-   Why include interactivity elements to visualisations?
    -   Reinforce learning
    -   Increase classroom engagement
    -   Display technological proficiency
    -   Generational shift in expectations from digital natives

# Technicial <br> Challenages {.section-title background-image="Slides/section5.PNG" background-size="contain"}

## Persistent Storage {background-image="Slides/main.PNG" background-size="contain"}

```{mermaid}
graph TD
    A[User 1 - Laptop <i class="fa fa-laptop"></i>] -->|Access via Browser| B(Application Server <i class="fa fa-server"></i>)
    C[User 2 - Smartphone <i class="fa fa-mobile"></i>] -->|Access via App| B(Application Server <i class="fa fa-server"></i>)
    D[User 3 - Tablet <i class="fa fa-tablet"></i>] -->|Access via Browser| B(Application Server <i class="fa fa-server"></i>)
    B --> E[Shared Database <i class="fa fa-database"></i>]
```

## Abstract away complexity? {background-image="Slides/main.PNG" background-size="contain"}

Often we want R to carry out complex statistical logic on behalf of users and display some business outcome or aggregated summary to users. However our objective was to showcase this statistical logic!

Should we even be using an Shiny!?

> ...if written and mental arithmetic are secure. In both primary and secondary schools, teachers should use their judgement about when ICT tools should be used[^3]

[^3]: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/national-curriculum-in-england-mathematics-programmes-of-study accessed on 6th August 2024
